events.id: Amélie the Musical-Hannah Playhouse, Wellington, New Zealand-Wellington NZ
events.name: Amélie the Musical
events.venue: Hannah Playhouse, Wellington, New Zealand
events.long_description:
‘Amélie the Musical’ is set to enchant Wellington for its Australasian premiere. The show will play at The Hannah theatre in November. The Grammy and Olivier Award-nominated adaptation follows shy Amélie Poulain, who carries out small acts of kindness for those around her. 
Wellington’s Rachel McSweeney, who played Sophie in the 2025 production of ‘Mamma Mia!’, stars as Amélie. Gemma Hoskins is Amélie’s mother, and William Duignan plays the pop icon Elton John. A cast of thirteen takes on many roles, from greengrocers to goldfish. Produced by WITCH Music Theatre, the show captures the whimsy of the film that made Amélie a global favourite. It features a Grammy-nominated score by Daniel Messé and Nathan Tyson, as well as a witty book by Craig Lucas. Directors Maya Handa Naff and Nick Lerew, with music director Hayden Taylor, bring Amélie’s quirky world to life. The Guardian has described the musical as “a magical and emotional triumph”.

events.id: Christmas in the Quarters--Wellington NZ
events.name: Christmas in the Quarters
events.long_description:
All your favourite Christmas traditions play out across four Saturdays in November and December. The Wellington festive season has a suitably summer flavour with a host of fun activities brought to you by Wellington City Council. 
Christmas in the Quarters kicks off with Christmas crafts in Midland Park on Saturday, 22 November. There are five craft activities to enjoy, plus face painting. Kids can also post a letter in Santa’s letterbox. On Saturday, 29 November, the whole family can enjoy Christmas music and performances. There will be choirs, hip-hop dance, ukulele playing, and more. Chill out and absorb the sounds and sights of Christmas.

events.id: Pixies-St James Theatre, Wellington, New Zealand-Wellington NZ
events.name: Pixies
events.venue: St James Theatre, Wellington, New Zealand
events.description:
They influenced the sound of the 90s.
American alt-rock band Pixies formed in 1986.
Still popular more than 35 years later, they are heading to the St James Theatre for a two-night residency.
On the first night, they’ll play two 90s classic albums in their entirety – ‘Bossanova’ and ‘Trompe Le Monde’.
For the second night, they’ll play from their new album ‘The Night The Zombies Came’ plus other songs from their catalogue.

events.id: Pixies - 2025 New Zealand Tour-St James Theatre, Wellington-Under The Radar
events.name: Pixies - 2025 New Zealand Tour
events.venue: St James Theatre, Wellington
events.description:
PIXIES have announced a 2025 New Zealand tour which will see the alt-rock legends perform two consecutive nights in both Auckland and Wellington.
On the first night, they’ll play classic albums, 1990’s Bossanova and 1991 follow up Trompe Le Monde in their entirety, followed by a cross catalogue set and songs from their new album The Night The Zombies Came on the second night.
Pixies have just released their tenth studio album The Night the Zombies Came to critical acclaim, with MOJO saying, This most thrillingly deathly of bands remains alive and DIY stating, Pixies remain one of the most consistent, influential bands on the planet.
Pixies wowed UK fans in August with their mainstage performance at London’s All Points East, described as “raucous” by Rolling Stone UK after their sold-out Glasgow Academy show was tipped as “a full-on head rush of classics by the Scottish Sun and as relevant in 2024 as they were over 35 years ago by Glasgow World.
35 years since their groundbreaking Platinum-certified album Doolittle catapulted the band into the UK Top Ten, and 20 years since their celebrated reformation at Coachella, Pixies are deep into their second act, and in the midst of a creative purple patch.

events.id: Waiora Te Ūkaipō — The Homeland-The Opera House, Wellington, New Zealand-Wellington NZ
events.name: Waiora Te Ūkaipō — The Homeland
events.venue: The Opera House, Wellington, New Zealand
events.long_description:
The impact of colonisation and urban drift are themes in a theatrical reboot at the next Aotearoa New Zealand Festival of the Arts. ‘Waiora Te Ūkaipō — The Homeland’ was originally commissioned by the festival in 1992. Its return 34 years later at the 2026 festival is highly anticipated. It has become a landmark piece of New Zealand theatre — exploring the tension between past and future. Set in the summer of 1965, the play follows Hone, who brings his family from New Zealand’s East Cape to the South Island in search of a better life. As they gather for a beachside birthday hāngī with their Pākehā guests, buried secrets and cultural tensions rise to the surface. Far from their  tīpuna , the family must navigate questions of identity, belonging, and survival. 
Waiora Te Ūkaipō was conceived, written and directed by Hone Kouka (Ngāti Porou, Ngāti Raukawa, Ngāti Kahungunu). The multi-award-winning writer/director has penned 13 plays. Many have been staged in Aotearoa and further afield in Canada, South Africa, New Caledonia, and the UK. Waiora Te Ūkaipō is presented in partnership with the Aotearoa New Zealand Festival of the Arts, Te Ahurei Toi o Tāmaki Auckland Arts Festival, Auckland Theatre Company and Tawata Productions.

events.id: Heathers the Musical-The Opera House, Wellington, New Zealand-Wellington NZ
events.name: Heathers the Musical
events.venue: The Opera House, Wellington, New Zealand
events.long_description:
It’s Westerberg High, where popularity is a matter of life and death. Welcome to ‘Heathers the Musical”. Based on a movie with the same name, the show is a coming-of-age story dealing with love, heartache, defying expectations, and being true to yourself. It originally premiered in Los Angeles in 2013. Since then, the musical has had record-breaking seasons across the globe. It now makes its professional New Zealand debut in 2026, and Wellington is in line to join the school assembly. Described as a high-octane, black comedy rock musical, Heathers is packed with a mix of ballads and showstoppers. The catchy tunes are written by Kevin Murphy (Desperate Housewives) and Laurence O’Keefe (Legally Blonde: The Musical). 
The 1989 film starred Winona Ryder and Christian Slater. It quickly achieved cult status among audiences. Both the movie and musical follow high school student Veronica Sawyer. Veronica is just another nobody until she’s unexpectedly taken under the wings of the beautiful and cruel Heathers. When mysterious teen rebel J.D. arrives, Veronica learns that it might kill to be a nobody, but it's murder being a somebody. 
This special production will feature a stellar Australasian cast. So grab your scrunchies, break out the Corn Nuts and wait for the bell to ring.

events.id: PADI Open Water Diver Course-New Zealand Sea Adventures, 9 Marina View, Porirua - Mana-Event Finder
events.name: PADI Open Water Diver Course
events.venue: New Zealand Sea Adventures, 9 Marina View, Porirua - Mana
events.long_description:
This Course runs over the 11th, 12th, 18th and 19th of October not the 18th, 19th, 25th and 26th listed.

PADI is by far the largest and most popular Scuba diver certifying system in the world and for good reason. Courses are fun, safe, relevant, and packed with excitement! No matter what country you are in, your PADI qualification will be recognised.

The practical part of your Open Water Scuba Diver course takes just four days! During the first weekend, we make it very easy and convenient for you with our on-site dive pool (the only one in the Wellington Region). Our pool is where you learn to dive, so we can go at your pace, no matter how long it takes. During the first weekend, you learn and practice all the necessary dive skills. Once completed, you will be ready for the sea dives.

Once you are a certified diver, you will receive an eCard on your PADI App showing your qualification – and any PADI Dive Centre will be able to confirm your certification on-line. You will also be qualified to attend the PADI Advanced Open Water Diver course, and our regular Dive Days.

We want to make your diving safe and enjoyable. Welcome to the exciting world of Scuba diving!

If you have any questions please call, email or stop by our Dive Store.

Kind regards,
Tony Howell
PADI Course Director
Tel: 04 233-8238 Email: nzsa@scubadiving.co.nz Web: www.scubadiving.co.nz
9 Marina View, Mana, Porirua 5026


PADI Open Water Diver course at a glance:
•Digital theory: Open Water Diver eLearning Course (allow 8-14 hours)
•Practical: One weekend pool training, one weekend with four sea dives
•Options: One-on-one or unscheduled dates – additional costs apply.
•Start Time: Please be at NZ Sea Adventures by 8.30am daily.

Location:
We are located at 9 Marina View, Mana, Porirua; just north of the Paremata bridge on SH1. Look for the big yellow building. Check our website for location.

Prerequisites:
•Be at least 10 years old (special conditions apply for 10 and 11-year-olds)
•Be able to swim 300m (no time limit) and swim/float for 10 minutes.
•Be medically fit to dive. Check the Diver Medical Participant Questionnaire. If you answer YES to any of the questions or have any doubts, a visit to your doctor is required.
•Elearning must be completed before your pool training can begin.
•Complete the RDP Tables Quiz and Exam if you don’t have a dive computer.

What to Bring:
•Completed Diver Medical Participant Questionnaire.
•If Under 18 years – bring a Parent or Legal Guardian to sign your forms.
•A pen, swimming costume, towel and a snack for the breaks.
•Any personal dive equipment you wish to use.
•The $450.00 balance of your course fee.

Cost:
•Scheduled Open Water Diver Course Fee: total is $750.00; deposit is $300.00.
•Includes: PADI eLearning Course, Dive Gear Rental, Pool Sessions, and Sea Dives. Rental wetsuits are available in stock sizes only. Other sizes are available for purchase. Made-to-measure options can be ordered and purchased
•10% off all in-store purchases during your course. Does not include packages.
•$20 off your course fee for every person you get to sign on with you.

When:
Our PADI Open Water Diver Courses are scheduled year-round. See our online calendar for scheduled course dates or ask in store. Booking early guarantees your place and price.
Looking for different dates or smaller classes? Ask about our one-off course options. Let us know what you need and we will do our best to help (conditions may apply).

Booking your course:
•Course bookings can be made in-store, via email, online or over the phone
•The deposit of $300.00 secures your place on a course and purchases your eLearning course.
•Deposits are transferable to another person but are not refundable.
•Elearning courses, once redeemed, cannot be transferred.
•Before we can send you the eLearning link, we require your full name, date of birth, a valid personal email address and phone number.
•Your course balance is to be paid before we can begin your pool training.

events.id: How to Really Relax - Know your Mind, meditation class-174 Albert Street, New Zealand 4410,174 Albert St, Hokowhitu, Palmerston North 4410, New Zealand, Palmerston North-All Events In
events.name: How to Really Relax - Know your Mind, meditation class
events.venue: 174 Albert Street, New Zealand 4410,174 Albert St, Hokowhitu, Palmerston North 4410, New Zealand, Palmerston North
events.long_description:
How to Really Relax - Know your Mind, meditation class
How to Really Relax - Know your Mind, meditation class
with Kadam Birgit Saunders

On the surface of a stormy ocean, there are waves and there can be a lot of turbulence.
But the deeper we go below the surface, the more still waters become regardless of the weather at the surface.
By looking within our own mind, we can find similar stillness and refuge from the stress and chaos of our modern life and learn to really relax.

We’ll set off on a gentle voyage of exploration of our mind, developing our understanding of the way in which our mind is the source of our awareness, how thoughts and feelings arise from but always dissolve back into our minds.
We will become more familiar with the deep and profound sense of clarity and peace that arises when our minds are still and undistracted, and which discover our inner potential for peace, happiness and real relaxation.

During this course we will learn and practise meditations that will help us to experience mental clarity and inner peace by meditating of our mind.
We will explore how meditating on our own mind offers us the ability to let go of stress and worry by enabling us to get a clearer, more dispassionate view of our own thoughts and feelings.

DETAILS
Our general programme classes include Dharma teachings along with guided meditations. Each class is self-contained and is also presented as part of a series. Drop into any class you like. These classes are suitable for both beginners and more advanced meditation practitioners. No special clothing is required. Most people sit on chairs. Everyone welcome!

events.id: Messengers-National Library of New Zealand, 70 Molesworth Street, Thorndon, Wellington-Event Finder
events.name: Messengers
events.venue: National Library of New Zealand, 70 Molesworth Street, Thorndon, Wellington
events.long_description:
‘Animals first entered the imagination as messengers and promises,’ John Berger.
Messengers explores the enduring gaze shared between humans and other animals. The exhibition title is inspired by a line from John Berger’s seminal 1977 essay ‘Why Look at Animals?’ Berger argued that the relationship between humans and animals – ‘our unspeaking companionship’ – has been transformed by capitalism.
Messengers brings together historical and contemporary ways of looking at animals in photography and art. It features archival photographs from the National Library and Alexander Turnbull Collections, first taken by newspaper photographers in the mid twentieth century. The images capture everything from the polar bears once housed in Wellington Zoo, to an elderly gentleman standing amongst the life size concrete animal sculptures in his garden. These images are at once tender and loving, sentimental and silly, kind and indifferent.
Messengers places these archival photographs in proximity and conversation with contemporary sculpture and moving image works by four Aotearoa-based artists: Denise Batchelor, Brit Bunkley, Jane Dodd and John Ward Knox. From eerie AI and computer-generated animals to the hypnotic stare of a real live Ruru; from carved wooden godwits you can hold in your hand to ‘hominoid’ brooches, each artist’s work speaks to the ‘unspeaking companionship’ between humanity and other animals.
IMAGE Brit Bunkley, still from Transit, single channel video, 2025

events.id: Self-Guided Tour of Stonehenge Aotearoa-Stonehenge Aotearoa, 51 Ahiaruhe Rd, Carterton-Event Finder
events.name: Self-Guided Tour of Stonehenge Aotearoa
events.venue: Stonehenge Aotearoa, 51 Ahiaruhe Rd, Carterton
events.long_description:
Explore Stonehenge Aotearoa at Your Own Pace

Our self-guided tour includes a map and a 12-minute audio-visual presentation to help you uncover the secrets of the henge. Afterward, head down to the stone circle and try out its unique acoustics — clap your hands and hear the echo respond, or whisper and see how far your voice carries.

A self-guided tour typically takes around 30 minutes, but many visitors stay longer simply because it’s so much fun. The bigger your group, the better the experience!

Please arrive at least 30 minutes before closing time.
Available during our opening hours: 10 AM – 4 PM.

events.name: Shared 90-Minute Guided Tour
events.venue: Stonehenge Aotearoa, 51 Ahiaruhe Rd, Carterton
events.long_description:
Join a Shared Guided Tour and experience Stonehenge Aotearoa through the eyes of an expert. In this 90-minute journey, you’ll uncover how ancient cultures measured time, tracked the Sun and Moon, and connected the heavens with life on Earth.

Your experience begins with a captivating introduction and a 15-minute audio-visual presentation explaining how the Henge works. Then, step outside with your guide for a detailed tour of the stone circle, where astronomy, archaeology, and mythology come together in one unforgettable setting.

Perfect for visitors seeking a deeper understanding of the stars and stories that shaped human history.

events.id: Dianne Halliday, Organ-St Andrews on the Terrace, 30 The Terrace, Wellington-Event Finder
events.name: Dianne Halliday, Organ
events.venue: St Andrews on the Terrace, 30 The Terrace, Wellington
events.long_description:
Programme includes works by Carlotta Ferrari, Svitlana Ostrova, Jennifer Bate, Christina Harmon and Fanny Hensel Mendelssohn.


Dianne G Halliday has been active in the organ and church music scene in Wellington since her arrival in 1983. From 1984 - 96 she was Director of Music at the Metropolitan Cathedral of the Sacred Heart, establishing junior and adult choirs and bringing to fruition the expansion of the 1905 Hobday instrument to facilitate its use in contemporary Catholic liturgical practice. During this period she also succeeded in the Fellowship examinations for the American Guild of Organists. In 1997 she began a twenty-three year commitment to St Peter’s Church, Willis Street. Her activities there included the 150 the anniversary of the founding of the parish and continuing the annual Advent Lessons and Carols services. In 2014 she began DMA studies at the New Zealand School of Music at Victoria University, studying with Douglas Mews through 2018. In addition to the Wellington Organists’ Association, of which she is currently president, she has been active in the Royal School of Church Music, of which she was awarded an Associateship in 2023. She formally retired from St Peter’s in 2020 and is now active as a substitute organist and recitalist.

events.id: Mature Mountaineer's Talk: Geoff Spearpoint Reflects on His Journey-Tararua Tramping Club Inc., 4 Moncrieff St, Mount Victoria, Wellington 6011, New Zealand-Facebook
events.name: Mature Mountaineer's Talk: Geoff Spearpoint Reflects on His Journey
events.venue: Tararua Tramping Club Inc., 4 Moncrieff St, Mount Victoria, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
events.long_description:
Doors open 1.30pm, talk starts 2pm

Geoff Spearpoint will present a very personalised view of his career so far, bringing his passion for remote places to a wide audience.
Geoff began tramping in 1966 when he was 15, which grew into a passion for transalpine trips and climbing. He has had a variety of careers however employment has mostly been a means to an end, and his real career continues to revolve around the mountains.
He has been on expeditions to the Northern Patagonian Icecap, Himalayas, Karakoram Range, Yunnan and Tibet and worked in the Dry Valleys for Antarctica New Zealand. However, in the background, there were always transalpine tramping and climbing trips throughout the Southern Alps, where he explored interesting corners including the Ngapunatoru Plateau, Olivine Ranges, Volta, Hooker Wilderness, Cook area, Godley, Gardens, the Bracken Snowfield, and other remote places.
Geoff is perhaps best known for the books he has written, including his latest, ‘The Great Unknown’, a photo and text essay of Southern Alps wilderness trips, designed to encourage and inspire more journeys, and for his behind-the-scenes roles in successful television series. In recent years, Geoff has been actively involved in the care of our back country assets and is a founding member of the Backcountry Trust Board.
Enquiries:
Dave Bamford, dave@davebamford.co.nz Tel 027 457 0313
Andy Carruthers, chair@wellingtonalpineclub.org.nz Tel 021 244 6051

Mature Mountaineer meetings are a NZ Alpine Club initiative providing an opportunity for older members of the NZAC & affiliated clubs to get together, share and hear stories (usually from an invited speaker), and have afternoon tea. The intention is to provide a social gathering for those less likely to go out to evening events. The concept has been successful in Christchurch (since 2006), Auckland and Wellington. The functions are open to all interested outdoor enthusiasts and are made possible thanks to support from Tūpiki Trust.

events.name: Art Classes - Term 4 - Creative Kid's Art Lab - 2025
events.venue: Art Lab, 6 Rainbow Court, Raumati
events.long_description:
Art classes & after-school care for children who like to make, create and invent. Located in Raumati, Paraparaumu - Kapiti.

For ages 5-13 on Tues, Wed and Thurs. The kid's art classes are from 3.30 - 5.15pm, however children can arrive from 3pm onwards.


- Qualified primary teacher and artist
- 15 years' experience teaching art to primary-aged children
- Progressive teaching methods
- Lessons based on traditional and modern arts/crafts, developing skills & creativity
- Structured, but in a home-studio setting
- Daily or weekly themes
- A child-friendly, relaxed environment for after-school
- Lots of variety / choice
- Excellent resources

The classes provide an opportunity to play and experiment in a structured but caring, home-studio environment.

Activities are designed and supervised by an experienced primary school teacher and artist.

To meet the needs of active and curious children after school we explore a variety of crafts such as sewing, crochet, pottery, felting, weaving, jewellery and woodwork; and the art forms: painting, drawing, sculpting and printmaking.

The activities utilise a child's growing mathematical skills such as estimating, measuring, scaling up & down, changing 2D to 3D, exploring symmetry, and pattern-making. Natural sciences, such as chemistry, biology, geology and physics are included, as well as history and culture.

See the creativekids artlab website. Phone Helen with any questions.

events.name: Boost Your Business: Finance Foundations - PART 2
events.venue: The Dowse Art Museum and Dowse Square,45 Laings Road, Lower Hutt, New Zealand
events.long_description:
Boost Your Business: Finance Foundations - PART 2
Finance Foundations: Build, Fund & Future-Proof Your Business

About this Event

Come and join us this November in Lower Hutt for our Boost Your Business workshop series, Finance Foundations: Build, Fund & Future-Proof Your Business.

Whether you joined us last time or are coming along for the first time, this free, hands-on series is designed to help you feel confident and in control of your business (or future business) finances. Knowing what options are available to you as a business owner can make all the difference.

Part 2 with Sammie Price, Partnership Manager at HNRY
Sammie’s bringing the real talk on being a sole trader versus running a company. This one’s for anyone wanting clarity and confidence around tax, finance, and those “what am I actually meant to be doing?” questions that come with self-employment.
She’ll myth-bust common misconceptions, walk you through HNRY’s simple tools, and show you how to take the stress out of managing your finances, so you can focus on doing what you love.

If you’re a sole trader (or thinking about becoming one), this is the session you don’t want to miss! Get all your HNRY questions answered and walk away feeling more in control of your business journey.

Event Details:
Dates: 26 November 2025
Time: Doors open at 5:30 PM | Workshops run 6:00 – 7:30 PM
Catering: Dinner will be served at 6 PM by the amazing team at Amilagi’s Island Cuisine — so come hungry!
to sign up for part 1 of Finance Foundations on 12 November

Spaces are limited, so book your spot today!
You don’t need to be a Pasifika business owner to attend, everyone is welcome. Bring a friend and sign them up too!

events.name: EVENT: Presentation on Croatian Language, Culture, Science, Economy, and Language
events.venue: 32 Hania St, Mount Victoria, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
events.long_description:
A group of Croatian and Australian academics are touring NZ Croatian clubs in November, as a contribution to the celebration of the 1100th anniversary of the coronation of the Croatian King Tomislav. It’s a wonderful chance to engage with new ideas.
They will be at our club on Wednesday 26 November at 5.30pm (for a 6pm presentation). It is part of a project on “Science, Culture and Economy – Links between Croatian Communities in the World and the Homeland”.
The presentations are on:
- Brief history of Croatian standard language – Prof. Luka Budak (former Head of Croatian Studies, Macquarie University);
- World-renowned Croatian scientists and inventors – Dr. Marijana Borić, Scientific Advisor (Croatian Academy of Sciences and Arts – CASA);
- The Croatian economy from 1992 to the present day – Prof. Tomislava Majić, Senior Lecturer (University North); and
- Croatian language recognition in Australia in 1970s – Prof. Ana Bruning (former lecturer at Croatian Studies, Macquarie University and long-time Croatian language teacher at the Croatian Schools in Sydney.
The presenters acknowledge the support of Croatian Studies Foundation of Australia, Central State Office for Croats Outside of the Republic of Croatia, Foundation of Croatian Academy of Sciences and Arts.
Current timings for the event are:
5:30pm - gather for tea/coffee/drinks
6:00pm - Presentations
This will be followed by a question and discussion time, with a light supper and drinks.
All welcome! You don't need to be a member of the Club to attend!

events.id: FLINT Wellington: Get to know a CxO-level 6/44 Bowen Street, Wellington Central, Wellington 6011, New Zealand-Humanitix
events.name: FLINT Wellington: Get to know a CxO
events.venue: level 6/44 Bowen Street, Wellington Central, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
events.long_description:
Ever wondered what it really takes to make it to the top? Join us for an evening of speed networking with some of Wellington’s most inspiring executives.
At Get to Know a CxO, you’ll have the chance to move around the room and chat one-on-one with a range of senior leaders. Expect candid conversations about their career journeys, lessons learned, and the moments that shaped their leadership.
This isn’t your typical panel event. It’s relaxed, interactive, and designed to help you connect directly with the people behind the titles. Whether you’re curious about leadership, thinking about your next move, or just love hearing great career stories, this event’s for you.
Come for the insights, stay for the connections ✨
📅 Wednesday 26 November, 5:30 PM
📍 Venue: KPMG - Level 6, 44 Bowen Street, Wellington
🎙️ Speakers: 
Anna Darling, GM People Experience at Sharesies
Phillip Whitmore, Partner - Digital at KPMG
Anna Mitchell, Executive General Manager, Frontier at Chorus
More to be announced!
Spots are limited, with FLINT members taking priority over non-members so register now to secure your spot!
We look forward to seeing you there.
_______________________
About FLINT
If you’re in the early stages of your career and you’re interested in digital technologies, come join the FLINT programme in your local city. We host events, webinars, podcasts and social catch ups that offer valuable networking, learning and growth opportunities. 
Find out more about the Wellington FLINT team here.
  Anna Mitchell, Executive General Manager, Frontier at Chorus
Anna is Executive General Manager, Frontier at Chorus, with accountabilities for fibre footprint growth, copper exit, property optimisation, and corporate affairs, as well as championing Chorus’ sustainability and digital equity ambitions. She brings broad expertise in telecommunications policy and leading strategic initiatives, with experience across both public and private sectors, including roles at Deloitte, SweeneyVesty, and as a senior advisor to a cabinet minister.
  Philip Whitmore, Partner, Cyber and Digital at KPMG
Philip is a Partner within KPMG Cyber with over 30 years’ experience across a broad range of cyber security disciplines. He has worked extensively in New Zealand, as well as throughout the wider Asia Pacific region.  His cyber security knowledge and experience is supported by his wider business consulting background, giving him the ability to readily translate cyber security risks into a business context. Philip’s experience saw him win the New Zealand Cyber Security Person of the Year award in 2023.
  Anna Darling, GM People Experience at Sharesies
Anna is an experienced HR leader with 15 years’ experience across the public and private sectors in New Zealand and the UK. Passionate about human-centred design, she focuses on creating meaningful employee experiences and driving diversity, equity, and inclusion. Anna is especially committed to increasing Māori and Pasifika representation in tech and expanding opportunities for underrepresented groups, drawing on her background in developing women’s rugby and promoting gender equity in sport in Aotearoa. She also serves on the Board of Nuku Ora and was part of the Sharesies team recognised as the Overall 2025 Best Place to Work in October.

events.id: GROUNDWORK: an author talk with Michele Leggott and Catherine Field-Dodgson-61 Willis St, Wellington Central, Wellington 6011, New Zealand-Facebook
events.name: GROUNDWORK: an author talk with Michele Leggott and Catherine Field-Dodgson
events.venue: 61 Willis St, Wellington Central, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
events.long_description:
Join us to hear authors Michele Leggott and Catherine Field-Dodgson discuss Emily Cumming Harris, the subject of their book 'Groundwork', and one of Aotearoa's most significant female artists of the nineteenth and early twentieth centuries.
Just as Emily Harris’s beautiful paintings occupy a liminal space between scientific botanical illustration and art, so this book occupies a shifting ground between biography and imagineered monograph. The result is often moving and always intriguing. Importantly, it restores to Aotearoa art history a figure who had almost disappeared.
Emily Harris has been examined alongside her artist peers Sarah Featon and Georgina Hetley, but until this book neither her distinctive voice nor her almost 200 surviving images have been heard or seen in any quantity outside of archival or online spaces.
Her life story is remarkable and her diaries, letters, poems and paintings constitute a fascinating legacy. In 'Groundwork', with its compelling text, they are lovingly brought together for the first time.
Michele and Catherine will be bringing copies of Emily's hand-coloured book 'New Zealand Flowers, Berries and Ferns' to display.

events.name: Te Tipu Pakihi Māori Award Dinner
events.venue: 2 Taranaki Street, Wellington Central, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
events.long_description:
"Whakatupu: Igniting Māori Enterprise, Innovation, and Growth in Te Ūpoko o te Ika "
Tipu Pakihi 2025 Dinner is here to highlight Māori business growth, foster innovation, and strengthen collaboration across Te Ūpoko o te Ika. Grounded in Māori values and whanaungatanga, this event brings together Māori entrepreneurs, rangatahi, iwi leaders, innovators, business networks, and support agencies to shape a thriving regional Māori economy.
Expect a delicious dinner, awards for successful Māori entrepreneurs, extended networking opportunities, and outstanding entertainment. From rangatahi start-ups to iwi investment strategies, Tipu Pakihi is a space where ideas are nurtured, partnerships are formed, and solutions are co-designed for Māori-led economic development.
This is more than just dinner. It’s a celebration of our people, our creativity, and our future. Come ready to eat, connect, and be moved. The vibes will be high, the kaupapa strong, and the memories lasting.
Whether you're starting out, scaling up, or supporting Māori enterprise, Tipu Pakihi 2025 offers connection, inspiration, and actionable insights.

Spring League at Harcourt park is returning
Mark Wednesday the 29th October - 17 December 2025 on the calender, as this is the start of the next PDGA sanctioned league at Harcourt park, Upper Hutt brought to you by the Greater Wellington Disc Golf Club.
The league will be for 8 weeks til 5th and offer divisions by PDGA rating. If you don’t have a rating TD will assign you to a ratings group based on level of skill and experience.
Costs for the league is preferred to pay in advance or at first round and priorty will go to club members if the league reaches greater than 45 participants.

$10 for Greater Wellington disc golf club members
$20 for Non club member (required to pay in advance of league or on first day of play).
$5 for casual play (required to pay on day of round).
League fees can be paid in cash on the night or direct into the club league account (preferred). Please use Spring25 & your last name as reference.
Kiwi Bank: 38-9016-0650973-03
Prizes - Divisional Winners will receive braging rights, two prizes will be provided to the 2 participants that shoot the most points above their rating in a single round (every one has a change at taking this one out)
Also there will be an optional extra jackpotting ace kitty. For the league. How to enter - gold coin entry each week. To be in the running for the week need to have paid in. Eg so week one pay $1 and in if hit an ace, week 2 not pay in therefore no entry into ace kitty, week 3 pay into ace kitty. Hit an ace week 2 can’t claim the kitty as did not pay in, hit an ace week 3 collect the ace kitty (shared if others also hit an ace that week).

events.id: Robin Hood - The Pantomime-Circa Theatre, 1 Taranaki St, Wellington-Event Finder
events.name: Robin Hood - The Pantomime
events.venue: Circa Theatre, 1 Taranaki St, Wellington
events.long_description:
Adventures of the original working-class hero and man in tights!

Robin Hood steals from the rich and gives to the poor in an oldie timey place where people are struggling and homeless and the landed gentry hoard the money all for themselves – Wellington 2025.

Robin must stop the Evil Sheriff from running roughshod over the citizens! But this quest is far from easy… there is archery, swordfights, and a lot of dance numbers to get through. Our hero is grateful for help from spies on the inside: Maid Marion, and her bolshie Nanny (Pantomime Dame Jthan Morgan).

Come one and come all to see the slings and arrows of outrageous panto!


Written by Simon Leary & Gavin Rutherford
Directed by Gavin Rutherford
Musical Direction and Arrangements by Michael Nicholas Williams

events.id: Sunset Guided Tour-Stonehenge Aotearoa, 51 Ahiaruhe Rd, Carterton-Event Finder
events.name: Sunset Guided Tour
events.venue: Stonehenge Aotearoa, 51 Ahiaruhe Rd, Carterton
events.long_description:
Experience Stonehenge Aotearoa at its most breathtaking — as the sun dips below the Wairarapa horizon.
Our Sunset Guided Tour blends astronomy, storytelling, and the natural beauty of twilight for an evening you will never forget.

Led by one of our knowledgeable guides, this 90-minute experience explores how ancient cultures used the Sun to track time and mark the turning of the seasons. You’ll discover the scientific and cultural thinking behind the Henge’s unique Southern Hemisphere design before watching the sunset alignment from inside the stone circle.

Weather permitting, you’ll witness how the setting Sun interacts with the structure — a striking moment that links ancient knowledge with the rhythms of the natural world.

Duration and Schedule
• Allow: Approximately 90 minutes
• Start Time: Begins one hour before sunset
• Availability: Offered any day with advance booking

events.id: Amélie the Musical-Hannah Playhouse, 12 Cambridge Terrace, Te Aro, Wellington-Event Finder
events.name: Amélie the Musical
events.venue: Hannah Playhouse, 12 Cambridge Terrace, Te Aro, Wellington
events.long_description:
Following the success of its critically-acclaimed 2019–2022 UK production—which earned a GRAMMY® nomination and three Olivier Award nominations—Amélie the Musical now makes its Aotearoa New Zealand premiere at the Hannah Playhouse this November 14 – 29, 2025, starring Rachel McSweeney as Amélie Poulain.

Inspiring, whimsical, and brimming with heart, Amélie the Musical brings Jean-Pierre Jeunet’s five-time Oscar-nominated film to the stage with wit and charm. The show follows Amélie, an extraordinary but shy young woman who lives vividly inside her own imagination. She secretly improvises small acts of mischief and kindness for those around her. When an unexpected chance at love comes her way, Amélie realizes she’ll need to move beyond the lonely isolation of her youth and allow herself to be truly seen.

Featuring an original score by Daniel Messé and Nathan Tysen, and a book by two-time TONY Award® nominee Craig Lucas (The Light in the Piazza, An American in Paris), Amélie the Musical transports audiences into Amélie’s fantastical world. The audience watches as she discovers her voice, uncovers the power of human connection, and finds new possibilities around every corner.

“Illustrates the profound imaginative power of theatre” – The Times
“A magical and emotional triumph.” – The Guardian
events.description:
Following the success of its critically-acclaimed 2019–2022 UK production—which earned a GRAMMY® nomination and three Olivier Award nominations—Amélie the Musical now makes its Aotearoa New Zealand premiere at the Hannah Playhouse this November 14 – 29, 2025, starring Rachel McSweeney as Amélie Poulain.
Inspiring, whimsical, and brimming with heart, Amélie the Musical brings Jean-Pierre Jeunet’s five-time Oscar-nominated film to the stage with wit and charm.

She secretly improvises small acts of mischief and kindness for those around her.
When an unexpected chance at love comes her way, Amélie realizes she’ll need to move beyond the lonely isolation of her youth and allow herself to be truly seen.

events.id: Every Kind Of Weather-Circa Theatre, 1 Taranaki St, Wellington-Event Finder
events.name: Every Kind Of Weather
events.venue: Circa Theatre, 1 Taranaki St, Wellington
events.long_description:
A theatrical double-shot from an iconic playwright and one of our greatest actors.

Bruce Mason is perhaps the most significant playwright in Aotearoa New Zealand’s theatrical history. Writing with courage and insight, he was a lover of language and a champion of the underdog.

Between 1959 and 1978, Bruce toured the country, telling uniquely Kiwi stories about emerging identity, cultural cringe and social difference. From church halls to country shearing sheds to the Edinburgh Festival, Bruce would play anywhere, in any circumstance, to any audience.

To celebrate his extraordinary legacy, Brilliant Adventures and Circa Theatre are collaborating to make two of his greatest solo works resound for a new age.

Two plays: timeless, universal, distinct. Following their critically acclaimed, sold out run of THINGS I KNOW TO BE TRUE, actor Stephen Lovatt and director Shane Bosher return to Circa for a not-to-be missed theatrical encounter with a master craftsman.

THE END OF THE GOLDEN WEATHER
“I invite you to join me, in a voyage into the past, to that territory of the heart we call childhood.”

Bruce Mason’s quintessential Kiwi classic chronicles the friendship between a 12-year-old boy and Firpo, a social outcast who dreams of winning an Olympic medal.

Through the boy’s eyes we see the wonder of life on a perfect beach, in a perfect 1930s New Zealand, during a perfect summer. It’s a world of magic and transformation, where anything can happen and miracles seem possible.

When the boy sets out to help Firpo make his athletic dream a reality, ignoring his father’s rebukes and community ridicule, a battle rages between the eternal optimism of childhood and the harsh pragmatism of adulthood.

Gliding effortlessly between flights of poetic fancy and blunt everyday speech, THE END OF THE GOLDEN WEATHER is New Zealand storytelling at its very best.

NOT CHRISTMAS, BUT GUY FAWKES
An adolescent boy tries to find his place in an adult-dominated world. A young man retraces an intensely felt boyhood experience of bullying. A playwright in his last days reconciles the value of an artistic life and challenges the idea of New Zealand identity.

Comic disasters and confronting your own hubris. NOT CHRISTMAS, BUT GUY FAWKES is a richly autobiographical search for self-expression. Profound and true, it is a set of variations about over-reaching, cheekily confronting our very own Tall Poppy Syndrome.

Celebrating Bruce Mason
Directed by Shane Bosher
Performed by Stephen Lovatt

Thursday 20 November to Saturday 13 December
Preview Night: Wed 19 Nov – The End of the Golden Weather
Preview Night: Fri 21 Nov – Not Christmas, But Guy Fawkes
Sunday Special: Sunday 23 November – The End of the Golden Weather
Q&A: Tuesday 25 November
Choose Your Price Night: Wed 26 November – Not Christmas, But Guy Fawkes
Circa Two
Tues – Fri 7.30pm, Sat 4.30pm & 7.30pm, Sun 4.30pm
$30 – $60 Early Bird Tickets Available

Productions play on alternate nights with an opportunity to see both productions in conversation with each other on Saturdays

When the boy sets out to help Firpo make his athletic dream a reality, ignoring his father’s rebukes and community ridicule, a battle rages between the eternal optimism of childhood and the harsh pragmatism of adulthood.

events.id: Gaza Surf Club - Wellington film screening-93 Mornington Road, Brooklyn, Wellington 6021, New Zealand-Humanitix
events.name: Gaza Surf Club - Wellington film screening
events.venue: 93 Mornington Road, Brooklyn, Wellington 6021, New Zealand
events.long_description:
🌊 Gaza Surf Club - Film Screening & Fundraiser 🌊
Join us for a community screening at Vogelmorn (Upstairs) Wednesday Nov 26th at 7.30pm.
Gaza Surf Club offers insight into the lives of the Palestinian surfing community and their connection to the sea, as well as the ongoing struggles of living under a military occupation. 
Tickets are koha / pay what you can style and will go directly to supporting Sabah Abu Ghanem (a surfer featured in the film) and her family.
What to know for the screening
This is a relaxed event for all those (surfing community or not) who would like to support Sabah and raise awareness about the challenges of attempting to surf under Israeli military occupation in Gaza. 
The venue won't be operating its restaurant during the screening so you are encouraged to BYO snacks or dinner if you wish.
Unfortunately the venue is not wheelchair accessible.
About Sabah
Sabah has been surfing since she was a little girl and has been featured in several documentaries (including Gaza Surf Club). She was taught by her father, Rajab Abu Ghanem who is a renowned fisherman and surfer in Gaza. It was Sabah's dream to start the first girls swim and surf club in Gaza.
Now 26, Sabah has three children and her focus is on the survival of her family.
Here is a link to a recent article she is featured in if you want to follow her journey:
https://www.nytimes.com/2025/10/19/world/middleeast/gaza-city-israel-hamas-cease-fire.html
For more information on Gaza Surf Club, or to support other members of the Gaza surfing community, follow @surfersforpalestine and check out the Gaza Surf Club website.
If you have any questions, reach out to me (Adriana Bird) via instagram @adriana_bird
Hope to see you on Wednesday 26th Nov!

events.long_description:
The New Zealand School of Dance (NZSD) Performance Season is a highlight of the School calendar and a showcase of the extraordinary dedication and passion the students apply to their training throughout the year.

Students from both the classical ballet and contemporary dance streams will showcase their talent in a series of performances allowing audiences of family, friends, supporters and dance enthusiasts the opportunity to see the rising talent of the future.

This year’s event celebrates the huge contribution of the School to the dance landscape in Aotearoa and beyond, with many of the works created by and/or staged by NZSD graduates. The 2025 season demonstrates the diversity of the art form – showcasing luminary new choreographic voices of contemporary dance, while paying homage to the timeless foundations of classical ballet.

A season of 10 performances, showcasing two separate programmes of classical ballet and contemporary dance, where the students will display their extraordinary talent, to audiences of family, friends and dance lovers. The split programme this year features a bold selection of works showcasing both the technical prowess and artistry of these young dancers.

events.id: Not Christmas, but Guy Fawkes-Circa Theatre, 1 Taranaki St, Wellington-Event Finder
events.name: Not Christmas, but Guy Fawkes
events.venue: Circa Theatre, 1 Taranaki St, Wellington
events.long_description:
A theatrical double-shot from an iconic playwright and one of our greatest actors.

Bruce Mason is perhaps the most significant playwright in Aotearoa New Zealand’s theatrical history. Writing with courage and insight, he was a lover of language and a champion of the underdog.

Between 1959 and 1978, Bruce toured the country, telling uniquely Kiwi stories about emerging identity, cultural cringe and social difference. From church halls to country shearing sheds to the Edinburgh Festival, Bruce would play anywhere, in any circumstance, to any audience.

To celebrate his extraordinary legacy, Brilliant Adventures and Circa Theatre are collaborating to make two of his greatest solo works resound for a new age.

Two plays: timeless, universal, distinct. Following their critically acclaimed, sold out run of THINGS I KNOW TO BE TRUE, actor Stephen Lovatt and director Shane Bosher return to Circa for a not-to-be missed theatrical encounter with a master craftsman.


THE END OF THE GOLDEN WEATHER
“I invite you to join me, in a voyage into the past, to that territory of the heart we call childhood.”

Bruce Mason’s quintessential Kiwi classic chronicles the friendship between a 12-year-old boy and Firpo, a social outcast who dreams of winning an Olympic medal.

Through the boy’s eyes we see the wonder of life on a perfect beach, in a perfect 1930s New Zealand, during a perfect summer. It’s a world of magic and transformation, where anything can happen and miracles seem possible.

When the boy sets out to help Firpo make his athletic dream a reality, ignoring his father’s rebukes and community ridicule, a battle rages between the eternal optimism of childhood and the harsh pragmatism of adulthood.

Gliding effortlessly between flights of poetic fancy and blunt everyday speech, THE END OF THE GOLDEN WEATHER is New Zealand storytelling at its very best.


NOT CHRISTMAS, BUT GUY FAWKES
An adolescent boy tries to find his place in an adult-dominated world. A young man retraces an intensely felt boyhood experience of bullying. A playwright in his last days reconciles the value of an artistic life and challenges the idea of New Zealand identity.

Comic disasters and confronting your own hubris. NOT CHRISTMAS, BUT GUY FAWKES is a richly autobiographical search for self-expression. Profound and true, it is a set of variations about over-reaching, cheekily confronting our very own Tall Poppy Syndrome.

Celebrating Bruce Mason
Directed by Shane Bosher
Performed by Stephen Lovatt

Please note The End of the Golden Weather and Not Christmas, but Guy Fawkes tickets need to be purchases separately, see the Circa Theatre website for full dates and ticket details.

events.id: High Dependency Unit with Special Guest W.I.T.C.H - Wellington-92 Vivian St, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand-Facebook
events.name: High Dependency Unit with Special Guest W.I.T.C.H - Wellington
events.venue: 92 Vivian St, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
events.long_description:
After close to a decade away from live stages, the mighty High Dependency Unit return this November announcing their first shows since 2016 including a key festival performance at The Others Way, and an all ages show in Port Chalmers to kick off the tour.
Since their formation in 1993, HDU have carved out a singular space in Aotearoa’s music landscape, fusing and funneling shoegaze and psychedelic noise into hypnotic, sonic power. Their live shows are the stuff of legend, their studio output of essential albums and EPs through the 90s and 2000s have become touchstones for generations of musicians both here and abroad.
The return of Tristan Dingemans, Neil Phillips, and Constantine Karlis to the stage and a rare chance to witness HDU in full flight is nothing short of a seismic event. These November dates will see the band revisit their formidable back catalogue and remind audiences why they’ve long been considered one of New Zealand’s most powerful live acts.
Adding to the magic of the incoming High Dependency Unit NZ tour, HDU’s Wellington Meow Nui show will feature very special guests W.I.T.C.H. on the bill. The legendary 1970s Zamrock pioneers whose psychedelic rock, funk, and African rhythms have made them cult icons around the world, W.I.T.C.H. (We Intend To Cause Havoc) are in the midst of a global renaissance, bringing their irresistible live energy to new generations making this one-off pairing with HDU an utterly unmissable night.

Banished Music pre-sale - Friday 29 August, 10AM
General on sale - Monday 1 September, 10AM
Tickets & Info from Banished Music
Subscribe to presale at banishedmusic.com/subscribe

events.id: Home, I'm Darling-Studio 73, 73 Main Street, Greytown-Event Finder
events.name: Home, I'm Darling
events.venue: Studio 73, 73 Main Street, Greytown
events.long_description:
The first Greytown Little Theatre production to be presented in the upgraded Studio 73 will be ‘Home, I'm Darling’ - a play by British playwright Laura Wade and will be directed by Victoria Ross.
‘Home, I’m Darling’ opens on Wednesday 19 November for a nine performance season.

The cast has some new faces and regulars returning to the GLT stage and includes Judy - Katie Cooper, Johnny - Egan Tearle, Fran - Lisa McLeod, Marcus - Greg Webb, Sylvia - Jo Crimp, Alex - Anna Logan.
Victoria Ross, the Director, describes ‘Home, I’m Darling’, as a witty-thought provoking piece of theatre and is a play that explores obsession and feminism and asks the question, ‘Have we evolved since the 1950s?’

Since its 2018 debut at Theatr Clwyd, the play has been performed in the West End and toured the UK, as well new productions in Australia and New Zealand. It has won several awards.

events.id: How to Really Relax - Know your Mind - meditation class-Ashhurst Village Valley Centre,21 Guildford St, Ashhurst 4810, New Zealand, Ashhurst-All Events In
events.name: How to Really Relax - Know your Mind - meditation class
events.venue: Ashhurst Village Valley Centre,21 Guildford St, Ashhurst 4810, New Zealand, Ashhurst
events.long_description:
How to Really Relax - Know your Mind - meditation class
How to Really Relax - Know your Mind, meditation class
with Kadam Birgit Saunders

On the surface of a stormy ocean, there are waves and there can be a lot of turbulence.
But the deeper we go below the surface, the more still waters become regardless of the weather at the surface.
By looking within our own mind, we can find similar stillness and refuge from the stress and chaos of our modern life and learn to really relax.

We’ll set off on a gentle voyage of exploration of our mind, developing our understanding of the way in which our mind is the source of our awareness, how thoughts and feelings arise from but always dissolve back into our minds.
We will become more familiar with the deep and profound sense of clarity and peace that arises when our minds are still and undistracted, and which discover our inner potential for peace, happiness and real relaxation.

During this course we will learn and practise meditations that will help us to experience mental clarity and inner peace by meditating of our mind.
We will explore how meditating on our own mind offers us the ability to let go of stress and worry by enabling us to get a clearer, more dispassionate view of our own thoughts and feelings.

DETAILS
Our general programme classes include Dharma teachings along with guided meditations. Each class is self-contained and is also presented as part of a series. Drop into any class you like. These classes are suitable for both beginners and more advanced meditation practitioners. No special clothing is required. Most people sit on chairs. Everyone welcome!

events.long_description:
Beauty & The Beast, a hilarious pantomime by Ben Crocker, directed by Samantha Baxter
Marlborough Repertory Society Presents: Beauty and the Beast – The Panto!

This year, Marlborough Repertory Society is bringing Ben Crocker’s hilarious panto Beauty and the Beast to the stage – directed by Samantha Baxter, it’s guaranteed to be a magical, laugh-out-loud treat for the whole family!
Expect outrageous costumes, witty one-liners, larger-than-life characters, toe-tapping songs, and plenty of the classic panto silliness that will have audiences of all ages shouting, cheering, and laughing from start to finish.

Join Felix, a loveable French Poodle as he tells this tale as old as time....with a twist. Why you’ll love it:
● A fresh, funny spin on the beloved fairy tale.
● Packed with comedy, music, and magical moments.
● Traditional panto fun – “Oh yes it is!”
● Brought to life by the talent and energy of your local Marlborough Repertory Society performers. This sparkling production is perfect for kids, parents, grandparents – and anyone who loves a good laugh and a great night out at the theatre.

This year we're making sure the shows start at Family Friendly times, so everyone can come and also be fresh for school and work the next day, or choose from one of the 3 matinee performances!

Don’t miss Marlborough Repertory Society’s Beauty and the Beast – directed by Samantha Baxter ! A magical community theatre event that will warm your heart, tickle your funny bone, and leave you humming all the way home.

events.id: Cultivating a Positive Workplace Culture for High-Performance Teams-Level 13 157 Lambton Quay Wellington, 6011-Event Brite
events.name: Cultivating a Positive Workplace Culture for High-Performance Teams
events.venue: Level 13 157 Lambton Quay Wellington, 6011
events.long_description:
This course is designed for leaders, managers, and organisational change agents who want to foster a positive workplace culture that drives high performance, collaboration, and employee wellbeing. Participants will explore the essential principles of creating an environment that nurtures trust, accountability, inclusivity, and engagement. Through practical strategies, case studies, and interactive discussions, participants will learn how to develop a culture that motivates teams to excel, encourages open communication, and supports professional growth.

Key Topics Include:
• Building a culture of trust and psychological safety
• Fostering open communication and feedback loops
• Aligning values and purpose with organisational goals
• Promoting inclusivity, diversity, and belonging
• Recognising and celebrating achievements
• Encouraging work-life balance and wellbeing
• Developing strategies for conflict resolution and collaboration
By the end of the course, participants will have the tools and insights needed to create a workplace environment that not only supports but accelerates the success of high-performing teams, driving both individual and collective achievement.

Key audience:
This course is designed for leaders, managers, and anyone responsible for shaping the culture within their teams and organisations.

Learning outcomes:
Implement strategies to cultivate trust, psychological safety, and high performance within their teams.
Lead teams that foster open communication, collaboration, and inclusivity.
Align team goals with organisational values and objectives, ensuring a shared sense of purpose.
Develop effective strategies for conflict resolution and team cohesion.
Create a workplace culture that encourages growth, well-being, and work-life balance.

If you would like to register with Business Central directly and receive an invoice for payment, please contact our training team via training@businesscentral.org.nz.

Course details:
Duration: Full day, in person.
Time: 9am – 4pm
Course includes
Workbook, arrival tea or coffee, morning tea, lunch, afternoon tea.
To view our Terms and Conditions click here.

events.id: Voices from the Moana: Amplifying Pacific stories of healing and resilience-42 Wainui Road, Waiwhetu, Lower Hutt 5010, New Zealand-Humanitix
events.name: Voices from the Moana: Amplifying Pacific stories of healing and resilience
events.venue: 42 Wainui Road, Waiwhetu, Lower Hutt 5010, New Zealand
events.long_description:
Talanoa Tai Learning is a new collection of learning experiences. They're designed to help you build your cultural responsiveness and improve your ability to engage meaningfully with Pacific communities. Talanoa is a Paciﬁc style of deep dialogue, with a focus on how we connect to each other and strengthen relationships, while still being able to share honest and eﬀective insights. Tai refers to ocean waters, which represent your opportunity to rise through the ebb and ﬂow of this learning journey. If you want to strengthen your capability in this space, to create transformational change, and to enhance your relationships with people from diﬀerent communities - this workshop is your chance to grow.
What will I gain from Voices from the Moana?
In Voices from the Moana, you will explore and share rich narratives of healing and resilience from different Pacific nations and perspectives. The Pacific ocean is a diverse place and we have our own unique stories of healing through traditional practices, beliefs and methods. This Talanoa Tai learning experience invites reflection on your own understanding of different healing modalities from the Pacific and the impact it has on your worldview. It will equip you to advocate for social justice through Pacific voices. You'll gain practical tolls and insights that you can apply directly to your work.
This is a 3 hour in-person learning experience.
Who is this workshop for?
These learning experiences are for both Paciﬁc professionals and those from other communities. You don’t need to have prior knowledge or experience in this area - we’ll meet you where you are and provide a welcoming, supportive environment for you to learn.
Cultural responsiveness is for everyone. Whether you’re in social work, education, government, community sectors or beyond, these learning experiences have been designed to help everyone build their skills. If you think this professional development might be right for you, it is!
Cost
When work is busy and budgets are tight, cultural responsiveness can often take a backseat. But this is an aﬀordable investment that will help you address the challenges that so many of us share, like how to build engagement and trust, and avoid relationship missteps. It’s not a buzzword; it’s a vital skill if you want to better meet the needs of the people you serve. Price: $170 (inc GST) per person, including morning tea.
 Facilitator
Our team’s extensive research and experience feed into these sessions, with a focus on interactive activities and practical, real-life examples. Our team has decades of experience across a range of ﬁelds, in particular social development, education, and research. We have worked with organisations and businesses across the Paciﬁc, and our engagement with diﬀerent Paciﬁc languages, cultures, and communities means we oﬀer robust, informed perspectives. Fa’aeafale’upolu (Polu) Samuelu is the facilitator of this Talanoa Tai Learning experience.

events.id: Karanga taonga, karanga tangata, karanga whenua |Reversing Cultural Amnesia: Activating Māori Practice in Museums-55 Cable Street, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand-Humanitix
events.name: Karanga taonga, karanga tangata, karanga whenua |Reversing Cultural Amnesia: Activating Māori Practice in Museums
events.venue: 55 Cable Street, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
events.long_description:
In 1947, Māori leader, politician, and scholar Apirana Ngata spoke to his scholarly peers at the Polynesian Society, announcing his greatest desire to revive Māori culture as a living force within communities, not be relegated to dead exhibits in museums (Ramsden 1948, 85).
This lecture acknowledges the concerns of visionary leaders and champions of cultural practice and their activation within museums. Through her work as a Māori curator, writer, cultural practitioner and post-doctoral researcher, Awhina Tamarapa advocates for cultural restoration as a form of liberation in a museum context. In her research, Tamarapa is exploring strategies for the recovery and reclamation of taonga puoro (singing treasures) and karetao (animated storytellers) for new generations.
There are challenges regarding taonga held by overseas museums. Concepts such as keeping taonga warm, and mana taonga, recognises the connection and authority of descendants to their taonga, that underpin this work.
The focus on the reclamation of Indigenous practice has been bolstered by working with First Nations, Canada BC. Led by Professor Bryony Onciul, University of Exeter, UK, Tamarapa was privileged to be part of a research project “The Future of Indigenous Rights and Responsibilities: Ancestral governance, environmental stewardship, language revival, and cultural vibrancy” funded by the Arts and Humanities Research Council, UK.
_________
The Michael Volkerling Lecture series is a partnership event with the Museum and Heritage Studies programme at Te Herenga Waka | Victoria University of Wellington, National Services Te Paerangi and Te Papa Tongarewa. This annual public lecture series recognises the legacy of the late Dr Michael Volkerling who was one of the principal architects of New Zealand's cultural and creative sectors.

events.id: Welly Biotech ‘n’ Beers: Speaker Series - November 2025-7 Dixon Street, Wellington 6011, New Zealand-Humanitix
events.name: Welly Biotech ‘n’ Beers: Speaker Series - November 2025
events.venue: 7 Dixon Street, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
events.long_description:
BioTech N Beers presents the third instalment of its speaker series, and the last BioTech N Beers of the year!  
 Once a quarter we will be running a fireside chat with those that have been there done that, the up and coming and everything in-between.
For our final meeting of the year, we are also working in collaboration with Women in HealthTech.
 Women in HealthTech:
Women in HealthTech is a collaborative group representing the HealthTech sector in New Zealand, providing a foundation of networks and leadership.
We have come together to empower women with a diverse range of thinking at all levels of the HealthTech industry and assist with effecting cultural change. Our steering committee represent companies across New Zealand from early stage start-ups and research medical technology companies, to privately owned New Zealand suppliers and global multinationals.
 Kindly hosted by Creative HQ our speaker will be Ipshita Mandal-Johnson telling us about her journey between building a bio revolution to revolutionising bio.
Generously sponsored by FB Rice, come along for a yarn, some war stories, and drinks and kai.
Check out Ipshita’s bio below and we hope to see you there!
 Ipshita’s Bio:
Ipshita has over 15 years' experience in academia, private and public sectors in bio sciences, technology and financial services.
She had completed a BTech in Biotechnology at the University of Auckland (co-funded by Douglas Pharmaceuticals) and a PhD in Chemical Engineering and Biotechnology at the University of Cambridge. She co-founded the Global Biotech Revolution in 2012, led the first GapSummit and growth of GBR activities including events in Singapore and the US till 2017 and is currently still a Steering Committee member. She also worked in a synthetic biology and chemistry biotech Nanna Therapeutics as CBO, which was eventually acquired by Astellas Pharmaceuticals for its rare disease pre-clinical assets. She then worked at McKinsey and Company in the India and US offices primarily in the technology, public sector and pharma practice areas (including as Chief of Staff to a $60Bn merger between Takeda and Shire). She has been an advocate for gender lens impact investing and women’s health through Global Bio Fund (invested in Baymatob in 2022 a med tech in maternal health) and the Xcellerator community.
She has provided advice to a portfolio of innovative and systemic investment projects in NZ through BioPacific Partners, Impact Lab, Malaghan Institute of Medical Research, MBIE funded RNA Development Platform and Advanced Technologies team. She is also passionate about bio systems thinking-philosophy and nature poetry. She has received multiple professional awards including thrice being listed in the UK 50 Movers and Shakers in Bio Business, selected to be a Leader of Tomorrow at the 43rd St Gallen Symposium and twice nominated as a Young Global Leader to the World Economic Forum (2024-25).
 FB Rice:
FB Rice is a leading independent intellectual property firm with a strong focus on biotechnology and the life sciences. With more than 75 years of experience and a dedicated Wellington office, we’re proud to support New Zealand’s growing biotech community through local presence and expertise.
Our Biotechnology Group brings deep scientific and industry knowledge across areas such as gene therapy, diagnostics, biologics, vaccines, and medical technologies. We work closely with clients across academia, research, and industry to protect innovation and support commercial success—offering strategic advice on patentability, prosecution, due diligence, and portfolio management.
As active participants in New Zealand’s innovation ecosystem, we value collaboration and are committed to helping the local biotech sector thrive.
 Creative HQ:
Creative HQ is a global innovation hub, based in New Zealand, that provides programmes for entrepreneurship and public sector innovation. Creative HQ creates change for governments and startups through innovation training, structured acceleration programmes and bespoke support.
Creative HQ, Wellington’s innovation hub, operates throughout New Zealand and internationally across the Asia-Pacific region with significant work experience in the Philippines, Singapore, Indonesia, Sri Lanka, Japan, Hong Kong, India and Australia. They look to build confidence, capability and connectedness throughout their ecosystem while looking to inspire and support the growth of individuals and businesses through the use of design thinking methodologies. This enables the delivery of innovative solutions to their customers.
 Event Details:
Date: Thursday, 27 November, 2025
Location: Creative HQ, 7 Dixon Street, Wellington 6011
Time: 4:30 pm – 6:30 pm
Cost: Free
events.description:
For our final meeting of the year, we are also working in collaboration with Women in HealthTech.
Kindly hosted by Creative HQ our speaker will be Ipshita Mandal-Johnson telling us about her journey between building a bio revolution to revolutionising bio.
Ipshita’s Bio: Ipshita has over 15 years' experience in academia, private and public sectors in bio sciences, technology and financial services.
She then worked at McKinsey and Company in the India and US offices primarily in the technology, public sector and pharma practice areas (including as Chief of Staff to a $60Bn merger between Takeda and Shire).

events.id: Optimising value through methodology - A PMO Case Study: Insights from NZ PMO of the Year 2025-Microsoft, Level 13 , 10 Brandon Street.-Humanitix
events.name: Optimising value through methodology - A PMO Case Study: Insights from NZ PMO of the Year 2025
events.venue: Microsoft, Level 13 , 10 Brandon Street.
events.long_description:
Note: This is a Hybrid Event:
In-Person Location: Microsoft, Level 13, 10 Brandon Street, Wellington.
Online: The Zoom link will be sent out the day before the event.
Networking will start at 5.00pm for the in person attendees followed by the presentation starting at 5.30 pm for both in person and online attendees
About this event:
“The New Zealand Traveller Declaration, that international visitors use today, is the product of over 200 dedicated team members working with focus, collaboration, and resilience over two and a half years through much adversity. It is a privilege to present insights from my experience as PMO lead in this remarkable programme team.”

Join Chris Fisher from Nonsuch as he shares personal insights into the award-winning New Zealand Traveller Declaration (NZTD) Programme, recognised as New Zealand PMO of the Year 2025 (and New Zealand Technical Project of the Year 2025)

Chris will reflect on his experience in the NZTD Programme that overcame complex national challenges to deliver a secure, user-centric digital border solution. He’ll unpack how the PMO supported the evolving nature of the programme and tailored methodologies in a hybrid model, blending agile, traditional, and benefits-led approaches to enable rapid delivery, strong governance, and measurable impact.

Chris will also highlight the practical application of frameworks that help power success, including the PMO Value Ring, and share what made the programme stand out in its PMI award application. Expect practical takeaways, lessons learned, and winning strategies that could help your programme, project, or PMO to drive value.

Whether you're leading a transformation programme or evolving your PMO, this session offers valuable insights into how integrated methodology can unlock real-world results.
About the Presenter:
Presenter: Chris Fisher – Head of Consulting, Nonsuch
Join Chris Fisher from Nonsuch as he shares personal insights into the award-winning New Zealand Traveller Declaration (NZTD) Programme, recognised as New Zealand PMO of the Year 2025 (and New Zealand Technical Project of the Year 2025)

events.venue: Wellington
events.long_description:
Āhuru Mōwai Trust High Sensory Sessions are held weekly at Chipmunks Playland Tawa.
Session Details:
When: Thursdays (Yes, even in the school holidays!)
Time: 5:30pm-8:00pm
Cost: $10 per family (immediate, not extended)
Who: children/young adults with special needs and their parents, guardians, family members, carers, siblings.
On Thursday's we also host Music Therapy Taster Sessions with our friends from the Little Musical Caravan. There is an additional activity fee of $5 per child to participate in that activity and a booking is required, If you are interested in these sessions register your interest directly with LMC via https://www.littlemusicalcaravan.co.nz/contact/
If you are looking to have a birthday celebration at one of these sessions please txt Paul on 0272787087, or message us in advance. We would also encourage you to make use of a party room to host additional guests (an extra charge would apply to guests)
Come along in any dynamic that suits the family, to these relaxed and open sessions for families and kids living with special needs of all kinds.
Although we cannot cater to everyone's needs, we will do our best to support families to overcome obstacles to attend the sensory sessions.
Please speak with trustees regarding concerns.
(I.D or needs verification may be required at Trustee discretion).
Disclaimer: WE WILL GENTLY AND KINDLY TURN AWAY ANYONE WE FEEL SHOULD NOT BE THERE, AND WE RESERVE THE RIGHT TO DO SO.

events.name: Advanced Yoga Class - Level 6
events.venue: Yoga in Daily Life Centre, 23 Jessie St, Te Aro, Wellington
events.long_description:
These classes are for anyone who has done yoga before and is ready for more advanced yoga postures, done with deeper inner focus and concentration. The Level 6 asanas and practices are advanced, and thus require a more concentrated and slow practice, with this the influence deepens. Each asana has a regulatory effect on the organs and glandular systems, the effects unfold during the asana and also during the short relaxation between each asana.

This level includes the practice of the Bhastrika - Pranayama.

Thursdays: 6 - 7.30pm

Drop in: $22 or 10 class card or holders of the Monthly passes

events.id: Author Event: Wild Swimming in Aotearoa-13 Constable St, Newtown, Wellington 6021, New Zealand-Facebook
events.name: Author Event: Wild Swimming in Aotearoa
events.venue: 13 Constable St, Newtown, Wellington 6021, New Zealand
events.long_description:
Join us for this fabulous event featuring three wild-swimming writers, each inspired in their own unique way by their connection to the ocean. Authors Ingrid Horrocks, Shona Riddell, and Kate Camp will be in conversation with host and wild swimmer extraordinaire Corrina Connor.
Meet our panel:
Ingrid Horrocks is a writer whose work spans poetry, travel, environment, and community. Her many books include the memoir Where We Swim, described as “a book about family that travels by water in the body of a swimmer”, Women Wanderers, as well as two collections of poetry. Her new collection of short stories All Her Lives was published by Te Herenga Waka University Press in October.
Shona Riddell is an author, journalist, podcaster, and swimmer. Her books include Trial of Strength: Adventures and Misadventures on the Wild and Remote Subantarctic Islands and Guiding Lights: The Extraordinary Lives of Lighthouse Women, both published by Exisle Publishing. She has a Master's degree (Science in Society) and hosts a podcast called Swim Chats where she interviews swimmers, coaches, and marine scientists. Shona says: “I like cold weather, being near the ocean (and swimming in it), and learning about remote locations”.
Kate Camp is an award-winning poet and writer. Her first collection of poetry, Unfamiliar Legends of the Stars, won the NZSA Jessie Mackay Award for Best First Book of Poetry at the 1999 Montana New Zealand Book Awards, and she has gone on to publish six more poetry collections, most recently the wonderful Makeshift Seasons (2025). Kate is also a reviewer and essayist and is a familiar voice on Radio NZ.
Meet our host:
Corrina Connor is a marathon swimmer, cellist and one of our very own librarians. Be it the beaches or pools, libraries or music, Corrina makes the most of the opportunities Pōneke provides, in both work and play. In the past few years she has taken on several marathon swims, including Te Moana-o-Raukawa (Cook Strait), Te Ara-a-Kiwa (Foveaux Strait), and Lake Taupō (a mere 40.2 kilometres); as well as undertaking several hypothermia-inducing ‘ice swims’, defined as swimming in water of five degrees or less.
This is a free event -- all welcome. Please note: we expect this event to be extremely popular, and seating will be on a first come first served basis.
events.description:
Authors Ingrid Horrocks, Shona Riddell, and Kate Camp will be in conversation with host and wild swimmer extraordinaire Corrina Connor.
Her many books include the memoir Where We Swim, described as “a book about family that travels by water in the body of a swimmer”, Women Wanderers, as well as two collections of poetry.
Kate Camp is an award-winning poet and writer.
Her first collection of poetry, Unfamiliar Legends of the Stars, won the NZSA Jessie Mackay Award for Best First Book of Poetry at the 1999 Montana New Zealand Book Awards, and she has gone on to publish six more poetry collections, most recently the wonderful Makeshift Seasons (2025).
This is a free event -- all welcome.

events.id: Laureates line up: A poetry reading-Te Ahumairangi Ground Floor, National Library, cnr Molesworth & Aitken Streets, Thorndon, Wellington-Event Finder
events.name: Laureates line up: A poetry reading
events.venue: Te Ahumairangi Ground Floor, National Library, cnr Molesworth & Aitken Streets, Thorndon, Wellington
events.long_description:
Come along to ‘Laureates line up’, a poetry reading event featuring nearly all living New Zealand Poets Laureate.

It’s been almost 30 years since John Buck created the Te Mata Estate Winery Laureate Award and Bill Manhire became our first Laureate. Both will be there to support an outstanding line-up of poets: Elizabeth Smither, Jenny Bornholdt, Michele Leggott, Cilla McQueen, Ian Wedde, Karl Stead, Selina Tusitala Marsh, David Eggleton, Chris Tse, and Robert Sullivan.

Fergus Barrowman, publisher at Te Herenga Waka Victoria University Press, will MC the event. There will also be special readings to honour the late Vincent O’Sullivan and Brian Turner, shared by Vincent’s son Dominic and Brian’s partner, writer Jillian Sullivan.

This free event promises to be a highlight of Wellington’s poetry scene in 2025.

events.id: Sushi Unfolded: A Vegan Demonstration & Tasting-175 Vivian St, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand-Facebook
events.name: Sushi Unfolded: A Vegan Demonstration & Tasting
events.venue: 175 Vivian St, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
events.long_description:
Sushi Unfolded: A Vegan Demonstration & Tasting
Back by popular demand! An evening of flavour, creativity, and connection as Balarama once again shares the craft of vegan sushi-making. From delicate hand-pressed pieces to beautifully rolled varieties, you’ll watch each step come to life in an engaging demonstration that’s both practical and inspiring.
Balarama’s grounded and approachable style makes the process easy to follow—even if it’s your first time exploring sushi-making. There’ll be space for questions throughout, and plenty of tastings along the way—so come hungry!
On the menu for the demo:
Hand-pressed sushi (Nigiri)
Sushi rolls (Maki-zushi)
Tofu pocket sushi (Inari-zushi)
Afterwards, stay on for a full vegan dinner and dessert, freshly served and enjoyed in good company—a deliciously relaxed way to spend your evening.
Meet Balarama, your chef & host
Say hello to Balarama, our amazing chef who’s always meditating on his next culinary creation. At Bhakti Lounge, he’s known for mastering a range of cuisines—from comforting classics to vibrant international dishes. Lately, he’s been exploring the delicate and artful world of Japanese cooking, crafting plant-based sushi that’s as beautiful as it is flavourful. Balarama’s goal is to make food that feels nourishing, thoughtful, and easy to enjoy—like a home-cooked meal made with heart. With his calm, down-to-earth style, he makes even the most intricate dishes feel approachable.
................................................................................................
Booking for Thursday is recommended!
For more details and to book please go here--
https://bit.ly/eventTickets

Wellington
